abstract.p: Bradley F Taylor letter on Aug 27 article holds directory-assistance providers, paid whether or not they have up-to-date data, have no incentive to improve service; drawing

block.p: Re your Aug. 27 front-page article about inaccurate directory assistance:
On several occasions, I've called information at 555-1212 to ask for a number that I know is listed and have been told, ''No listing.''
Re your Aug. 27 front-page article about inaccurate directory assistance:
On several occasions, I've called information at 555-1212 to ask for a number that I know is listed and have been told, ''No listing.''

Once, when I asked the operator where the company got its directory information from, she answered, ''We try to buy it from the local telephone company, but they don't always sell it to us, so we don't always have current information.''

You report that neither the Federal Communications Commission nor the New York State Public Service Commission receives many complaints about the problem. I believe that this is because when looking at their bills, people don't realize that they are charged for a ''no listing'' answer. And directory-assistance providers, paid whether or not they have up-to-date information, have no incentive to improve service.
BRADLEY F. TAYLOR Newtown, Conn., Aug. 27, 2000
